title: 104_hr3187
content: The "Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996" is also known as the Aviation Safety Protection Act. It includes a section on the protection of employees providing air safety information through a whistleblower protection program added to Chapter 421 of title 49, United States Code. The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996, also known as the Aviation Safety Protection Act, prohibits air carriers from discriminating against employees who provide information related to air safety to the Federal Government, file safety-related proceedings, or testify in such proceedings. The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996 prohibits air carriers from discriminating against employees who provide information related to air safety, file safety-related proceedings, testify in such proceedings, or assist in such proceedings. The Act also outlines the Department of Labor complaint procedure for individuals who believe they have been discharged or discriminated against in violation of the Act. The Aviation Safety Protection Act of 1996 prohibits air carriers from discriminating against employees who report safety concerns. The Department of Labor investigates complaints within 60 days, affording the accused an opportunity to respond and present witnesses. If the complaint is found to have merit, both parties are notified of the findings. If the Secretary of Labor finds reasonable cause for a violation, a preliminary order for relief is issued. Objections can be filed within 30 days, leading to a hearing. Failure to request a hearing within the specified period results in the preliminary order becoming final and not subject to judicial review. Within 120 days after a hearing, the Secretary of Labor issues a final order providing relief or denying the complaint. A settlement agreement can terminate the proceeding. If a violation is found, the Secretary orders the violator to remedy it. The Secretary of Labor can order the violator to take affirmative action to correct the violation, reinstate the complainant with back pay and benefits, and provide compensatory damages. The Secretary can also assess the violator for all costs and expenses incurred, including legal fees. The Secretary of Labor can order the violator to take corrective action, reinstate the complainant with back pay, and provide compensatory damages. The Secretary may also award costs and expenses, including legal fees, to the complainant for bringing the complaint. If a complaint is found frivolous, the prevailing employer may receive a reasonable attorney's fee. Adverse parties can seek review of the order in the United States Court of Appeals. The United States Court of Appeals has jurisdiction over reviewing orders issued by the Secretary of Labor within 60 days. Review process follows chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code, and does not automatically stay the order. Orders subject to review under this process cannot be judicially reviewed in criminal cases. The Secretary of Labor can enforce orders through civil actions in district courts, granting relief like injunctive relief and compensatory damages. Parties can also initiate civil actions against violators of orders issued under paragraph (3). The appropriate United States district court has jurisdiction to enforce orders issued under this section, and may award attorney fees and costs of litigation. Nondiscretionary duties can be enforced through mandamus proceedings under section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. The United States district court has jurisdiction to enforce orders related to air carrier safety violations. Attorney fees and costs of litigation may be awarded. Deliberate violations by an employee without direction from the air carrier are not covered under this section. "SEC. 3. CIVIL PENALTY. Amends Section 46301(a)(1)(A) of title 49, United States Code, to include protection under subchapter III of chapter 421 for employees providing air safety information."
